text: The song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth:
for thy love is better than wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of the savour of thy good ointments
thy name is as ointment poured forth,
therefore do the virgins love thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Draw me, we will run after thee:
the king hath brought me into his chambers:
we will be glad and rejoice in thee,
we will remember thy love more than wine:
the upright love thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem,
as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth,
where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon:
for why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou know not, O thou fairest among women,
go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock,
and feed thy kids beside the shepherds’ tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have compared thee, O my love,
to a company of horses in Pharaoh’s chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels,
thy neck with chains of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While the king sitteth at his table,
my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bundle of myrrh is my wellbeloved unto me;
he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text: My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of En-gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, thou art fair, my love;
behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves’ eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant:
also our bed is green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The beams of our house are cedar,
and our rafters of fir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the rose of Sharon,
and the lily of the valleys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the lily among thorns,
so is my love among the daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the apple tree among the trees of the wood,
so is my beloved among the sons.
I sat down under his shadow with great delight,
and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought me to the banqueting house,
and his banner over me was love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples:
for I am sick of love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left hand is under my head,
and his right hand doth embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem,
by the roes, and by the hinds of the field,
that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The voice of my beloved!
behold, he cometh leaping upon the mountains,
skipping upon the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is like a roe or a young hart:
behold, he standeth behind our wall,
he looketh forth at the windows,
shewing himself through the lattice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved spake, and said unto me,
Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For, lo, the winter is past,
the rain is over and gone;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the fig tree putteth forth her green figs,
and the vines with the tender grape give a good smell.
Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock,
in the secret places of the stairs,
let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice;
for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines:
for our vines have tender grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is mine, and I am his:
he feedeth among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the day break, and the shadows flee away,
turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe
or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth:
I sought him, but I found him not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will rise now, and go about the city in the streets,
and in the broad ways I will seek him whom my soul loveth:
I sought him, but I found him not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchmen that go about the city found me:
to whom I said, Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It was but a little that I passed from them,
but I found him whom my soul loveth:
I held him, and would not let him go,
until I had brought him into my mother’s house,
and into the chamber of her that conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem,
by the roes, and by the hinds of the field,
that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this that cometh out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
with all powders of the merchant?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold his bed, which is Solomon’s;
threescore valiant men are about it, of the valiant of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They all hold swords, being expert in war:
every man hath his sword upon his thigh
because of fear in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made the pillars thereof of silver,
the bottom thereof of gold, the covering of it of purple,
the midst thereof being paved with love,
for the daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold king Solomon
with the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals,
and in the day of the gladness of his heart.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet, and thy speech is comely:
thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate within thy locks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy neck is like the tower of David builded for an armoury,
whereon there hang a thousand bucklers,
all shields of mighty men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins,
which feed among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the day break, and the shadows flee away,
I will get me to the mountain of myrrh,
and to the hill of frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou art all fair, my love;
there is no spot in thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse, with me from Lebanon:
look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon,
from the lions’ dens, from the mountains of the leopards.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How fair is thy love, my sister, my spouse!
how much better is thy love than wine!
and the smell of thine ointments than all spices!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A garden inclosed is my sister, my spouse;
a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy plants are an orchard of pomegranates,
with pleasant fruits; camphire, with spikenard,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
a fountain of gardens,
a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south;
blow upon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out.
Let my beloved come into his garden,
and eat his pleasant fruits.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I sleep, but my heart waketh:
it is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying,
Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled:
for my head is filled with dew,
and my locks with the drops of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on?
I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door,
and my bowels were moved for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I rose up to open to my beloved;
and my hands dropped with myrrh,
and my fingers with sweet smelling myrrh,
upon the handles of the lock.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if ye find my beloved,
that ye tell him, that I am sick of love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is thy beloved more than another beloved,
O thou fairest among women?
what is thy beloved more than another beloved,
that thou dost so charge us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is white and ruddy,
the chiefest among ten thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His head is as the most fine gold,
his locks are bushy, and black as a raven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes are as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters,
washed with milk, and fitly set.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His cheeks are as a bed of spices, as sweet flowers:
his lips like lilies, dropping sweet smelling myrrh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His hands are as gold rings set with the beryl:
his belly is as bright ivory overlaid with sapphires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold:
his countenance is as Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mouth is most sweet: yea, he is altogether lovely.
This is my beloved, and this is my friend,
O daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women?
whither is thy beloved turned aside?
that we may seek him with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices,
to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine:
he feedeth among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah,
comely as Jerusalem,
terrible as an army with banners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn away thine eyes from me, for they have overcome me:
thy hair is as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing,
whereof every one beareth twins,
and there is not one barren among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples within thy locks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines,
and virgins without number.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Who is she that looketh forth as the morning,
fair as the moon, clear as the sun,
and terrible as an army with banners?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went down into the garden of nuts
to see the fruits of the valley,
and to see whether the vine flourished,
and the pomegranates budded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or ever I was aware, my soul made me like the chariots of Amminadib.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return, return, O Shulamite;
return, return, that we may look upon thee.
What will ye see in the Shulamite?
As it were the company of two armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O prince’s daughter!
the joints of thy thighs are like jewels,
the work of the hands of a cunning workman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy navel is like a round goblet, which wanteth not liquor:
thy belly is like an heap of wheat set about with lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!
speaker: Narrator

text:
This thy stature is like to a palm tree,
and thy breasts to clusters of grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, I will go up to the palm tree,
I will take hold of the boughs thereof:
now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine,
and the smell of thy nose like apples;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the roof of thy mouth like the best wine for my beloved,
that goeth down sweetly,
causing the lips of those that are asleep to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am my beloved’s, and his desire is toward me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field;
let us lodge in the villages.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The mandrakes give a smell,
and at our gates are all manner of pleasant fruits, new and old,
which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O that thou wert as my brother,
that sucked the breasts of my mother!
when I should find thee without, I would kiss thee;
yea, I should not be despised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother’s house, who would instruct me:
I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine of the juice of my pomegranate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left hand should be under my head,
and his right hand should embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that ye stir not up,
nor awake my love, until he please.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness, leaning upon her beloved?
I raised thee up under the apple tree:
there thy mother brought thee forth:
there she brought thee forth that bare thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Set me as a seal upon thine heart,
as a seal upon thine arm:
for love is strong as death;
jealousy is cruel as the grave:
the coals thereof are coals of fire,
which hath a most vehement flame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
neither can the floods drown it:
if a man would give all the substance of his house for love,
it would utterly be contemned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have a little sister, and she hath no breasts:
what shall we do for our sister in the day when she shall be spoken for?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If she be a wall, we will build upon her a palace of silver:
and if she be a door, we will inclose her with boards of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a wall, and my breasts like towers:
then was I in his eyes as one that found favour.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My vineyard, which is mine, is before me:
thou, O Solomon, must have a thousand,
and those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou that dwellest in the gardens,
the companions hearken to thy voice:
cause me to hear it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make haste, my beloved,
and be thou like to a roe or to a young hart
upon the mountains of spices.
speaker: Narrator
